answers.text: Adding a small amount of non-metallic carbon to iron

qas.question: What kind of metal is soft like copper?
What can be added to steel to enhance is corrosion resistance?
What is superior to pure iron?
What is another word for when alloys solidify?
What is produced by adding metallic carb and iron?
What type of metal is hardly copper?
The characteristics of what stay the same as it cools?
What is aluminum alloy the most common of?

context: When the <b8_0>alloy<b8_0/> cools and solidifies (<a4_0>crystallizes<a4_0/>), its mechanical properties will often be quite different from those of its individual constituents. A metal that is normally very soft and malleable, such as <a1_0><b6_0>aluminium<b6_0/><a1_0/>, can be altered by alloying it with another soft metal, like copper. Although both metals are very soft and ductile, the resulting aluminium alloy will be much harder and stronger. <a0_0>Adding a small amount of non-metallic carbon to iron<a0_0/> produces an alloy called <b5_0>steel<b5_0/>. Due to its very-high strength and toughness (which is much higher than pure iron), and its ability to be greatly altered by heat treatment, <a3_0>steel<a3_0/> is one of the most common <b9_0>alloys<b9_0/> in modern use. By adding <a2_0><b7_0>chromium<b7_0/><a2_0/> to steel, its resistance to corrosion can be enhanced, creating stainless steel, while adding silicon will alter its electrical characteristics, producing silicon steel.
